Got this on a super deep discount. My expectations for a 2K game were low, and I got about what I expected. Pass.

Prompt timings are bad.
CPU opponents ALWAYS hit the reversals and specials and kick outs perfectly. You better git gud, even from your first match.
Player controls sometimes gets confused, hit grab into a grapple or throw, and then your player sometimes just stands there holding the CPU player until they get out of it.
so realistic!

I have had a love for these games for a very long time. And this game seems like it would be a LOT of fun... If it all worked correctly. Online lobbies and quick play work just fine... However there is a major issue with My Rise that from what I have researched isnt an issue I alone have been experiencing... When you launch my rise all will appear normal, up until the match starts then all control input is ignored (or not event recognized) - I have gone through every suggestion I can find to try and resolve this issue - different input settings on steam, unplugging keyboard and mouse and launched in big picture mode, checking for any virtual devices or additional hardware being detected as an input device, even some more odd suggestions like launching it in normal mode and quickly unplug mouse - But still no matter what I have 0 ability to control the character in my rise. 

So if you are buying this for the My Rise campaign (like I did) think twice as currently its just flat out broken for some...

While I hope there may be a fix I doubt it as this is no longer the most recent release of the game :(

2K Games bad business has ruined this game. Their 1.21 "update" for the game does the following: Disable player mods. Severely limit Character creation and community shares to force you to buy their overpriced DLCs. Forcefully crashes the game if you simply open(not use) cheat engine. They create this artificial barrier by making you grind 100+ hrs in the game to unlock everything(characters, stages belts), or pay to unlock them all via a "DLC" purchase..

They intentionally didn't put bad bunny on sale to force you to pay full price for a complete collection. 2K also started killing ALL online services to force you to buy the "newer" version within 2yrs. WWE 2k22 got hit by that, and it's likely they'll do the same with this game.

This game series is unfortunately headed in the same direction as NBA 2K.
If only WWE would license this out to other publishers instead of exclusively to 2K...
PLEASE DO NOT SUPPORT THE BUSINESS PRACTICES OF 2K and avoid this game!!
Maybe it's because I don't watch WWE anymore & my mind stays pre-2012, with some exception to tuning in occasionally to AEW, but I really think the roster sucks... Even with all the DLC.

Universe mode is absolutely terrible.  Maybe the worst mode on any "sports" game.  You fight the same person 6 or 7 times in a row and then finish the rivalry at a ppv.  Like the fans want to see that 7th match after the previous six weeks of weekly matches between the two.

Also, I got put in a tag team rivalry without my tag partner. Instead i had another teammate added that was part of a different tag team.  And the worst part is after the rivaly finished I immediately got put in another tag team match with my not teammate as my teammate.  I can't skip the match. I can't change to classic mode. I can't go in and quit out to resign the match and I'm not wrestling it.  So i'm uninstalling it.  

I hate this game.  Seriously one of the worst times i had with a game in recent memory.  All because i broke out my ps3 and SVR2011 and had such a good time in universe mode. I thought they surely would have made the mode better after 12 years......but its somehow way worse in every way.  

I didn't expect this at all from a 2k game.  They always deliver quality game modes in all their previous sports titles.  I don't even like basketball and I still buy NBA 2k every few years because franchise mode is so good.   2k5 still has a better franchise mode than madden.

If you're buying this game for other things like the showcase, online, gm or the myrise, it may be ok.  I didn't try those.  But do not buy for universe mode. Its seriously terrible.

Breaking Kayfabe: A Promising Step Forward with Room for Improvement

Introduction:
WWE 2K23, the latest installment in the long-running wrestling simulation series developed by Visual Concepts, brings the high-flying action and drama of WWE to life with improved graphics, enhanced gameplay mechanics, and an extensive roster of WWE Superstars. With the promise of delivering the ultimate WWE experience, fans eagerly anticipated this release. In this review, we'll examine the highlights and shortcomings of WWE 2K23 and determine if it lives up to expectations.

Improved Graphics and Presentation:
One of the standout features of WWE 2K23 is its impressive graphics and presentation. The game boasts highly detailed character models, lifelike animations, and dynamic lighting effects that add a new level of realism to the in-ring action. From the iconic entrances of WWE Superstars to the bone-crunching finishers, every moment is brought to life with stunning visual fidelity that captures the spectacle of WWE events.

Enhanced Gameplay Mechanics:
WWE 2K23 introduces several gameplay improvements aimed at delivering a more fluid and responsive experience in the ring. The revamped grappling system offers better control over moves and counters, allowing for more strategic and dynamic matches. Additionally, the addition of new match types and mechanics, such as backstage brawls and environmental interactions, adds variety and excitement to the gameplay experience. While these improvements are a step in the right direction, there are still areas where the gameplay could be further refined for a more polished experience.

Extensive Roster and Customization Options:
WWE 2K23 boasts an extensive roster of WWE Superstars, past and present, allowing players to step into the shoes of their favorite wrestlers and compete in dream matches and rivalries. The game also offers robust customization options, allowing players to create their own wrestlers, arenas, and championships with unprecedented depth and detail. Whether you're recreating classic moments from WWE history or forging new legends of your own, WWE 2K23 offers endless possibilities for creativity and expression.

Challenges and Drawbacks:
While WWE 2K23 delivers on many fronts, it is not without its challenges and drawbacks. Some players have reported issues with bugs, glitches, and performance optimization, particularly in the online multiplayer modes. Additionally, while the roster is extensive, there are notable omissions and outdated character models that may disappoint longtime fans. The game's career mode also lacks depth and replay value, with repetitive objectives and limited storytelling options that fail to engage players in meaningful ways.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, WWE 2K23 shows promise as a step forward for the franchise, with improved graphics, enhanced gameplay mechanics, and an extensive roster of WWE Superstars. While the game delivers an authentic WWE experience with its stunning presentation and deep customization options, there are areas where it falls short, such as technical issues, roster omissions, and lackluster single-player content. With further refinement and updates, WWE 2K23 has the potential to become the ultimate WWE gaming experience that fans have been waiting for.

For the solo players: is it worth for the single player component alone? At a discount, yes.

I did the tutorial, created 2 custom characters and several movesets and only played the "the lock" campaign once to completion. I tried medium and hard difficulty, but medium became too easy quickly, taking away part of the enjoyment. Hard is the appropriate level to really experience the story.
All this together took me 28 hours. A, imho, decent deal for 20-25€.

As for this story, it starts really, really badly. The setup is that you are the new future champion, winning your first title in your very first WWE match (you were a British wrestler before). The problem is that this premise is boring because it is essentially a "Chosen One" story. You have to complete story fights and have optional "side fights", which are presented in the most boring way: a paragraph delivered by a non-character that means fight X. Why would you do that? Upgrade points, which you will need [or play on medium]. There is no meaningful decision-making here. So the actual story is weak and the side stories are less interesting than food labels. 
About 5 hours into the game I switched from hard to medium for a single reason: I wasn't having fun. I was skipping the tedious and irrelevant chatter of non-characters and had one difficult fight after another. It felt more like grinding. But I decided to press on because while I had bought the game at a sizable discount, it was still 20+€ and I wanted to get my money's worth. And I'm glad I did.
You see, what I described is just the first 40% of the campaign. Then a shift happens and suddenly your Chosen One isn't the Chosen One any longer, but an actual character. Other characters who by that point have only been window dressing suddenly develop a certain depth and...well, become actual relatable characters. (Voice work is also great.) Stakes are raised and the unexpected happens time and again. Is it at the level of War and Peace? No. (E.g. a lot of interaction with others is via text messages, you know the drill.) 
But after almost quitting the game, when I finally landed the last punch of the campaign, I shot my fist into the air and shouted "yeeeess!". After the tedious 40% I had started listening to the story again, and I turned difficulty back up to hard. 
To me, the campaign succeeded in what it set out to do.   
So if you belong to a niche within a niche of players who actually just want to play your avatar in a wrestling season, get it. At a discount.

And to the developers, writers and voice actors: why the flying F are the first 40% of the campaign such utter garbage when you the rest shows how incredibly entertaining you story and characters can be??!! (Cudos)

Don't really play wrestling games so take this with a pinch of salt. 

I love the old 80/90s wrestlers Rick Rude and Mr Perfect etc so wanted to try a game that had them in it. After a lot of research into which (modern) wrestling game to go for it was between 2k14, 2k19 and this .. according to the fans. 

So, I initially got 2k19 and it's great, a bit fiddly to install mods etc for my fav wrestlers but I'm getting there. 

Anyway, I saw a youtube video of 2k23 with Rick Rude and saw it on offer so decided to get it and see what it's like but straight away compared to 2k19 I didn't like it. Felt shallow and child-like, almost stupid. Even the animations weren't great so I immediately uninstalled. I couldn't help but think that a lot of hype and presentation goes into the new games but this one shows that the game-play itself is an after-thought. Maybe if I was 12 years old, mashing buttons while screaming at the monitor with my friends, it'd probably be an excellent game but as an older person looking a bit more substance and depth it's sorely lacking. It seems more and more modern games are becoming about how it looks and how slick and flashy it all seems but underneath the bonnet there ain't anything there. 

4/10.

I'm angry I enjoy this game. I heard about the modding scene and I was already loving the game, so I investigated and had my spirit crushed by both how many awesome looking mods there are for the game, and how 2K took a huge dump on the modding community and that none of the are playable. Hopefully rolling back my game version will let me play them. Game is good, but could be leagues better. I didn't know whether to give a good or a bad rating, so ill just let the rating reflect my spirit dying as I found out about the mod situation.

By far and away the biggest issue with this game is the removal of Quick Grapples and the attack on mod support. Yes, the Quick Grapples (along with Chain Wrestling) were removed for 2k22, but they are still missed here. Every grapple requires a lock-up presiding it in order to do a move, making every match a complete slog to get through and steadily sucks the fun out of each match. Don't let the other positive reviews fool you, many are of the casual persuasion and don't engage with this game for many great lengths of time. This might be ok for the causal gamer only passing through out of curiosity, but everyone else who expected a "Wrestling Game", as opposed to a watered-down, mortal kombat-esque fighting game, are just out of luck. The improved striking system, while not at all bad, replaces the Quick Grapple mechanic, greatly limiting gameplay feel. You wanted to wrestle in the style of a technical/mat-based or cruiser-weight wrestler? Your out of luck. The gameplay only favors Strikers and slow-moving giants. Fast moving gameplay is non-existent. 
And of course 2k's controversial decision to nuke the modding community is the biggest mistake they made. I bought 2k23 on PC solely for this reason, as 2k19's modding scene was fantastic. But this decision hurts them greatly. Replay value for this game (and 2k22 before it) is pretty low by wrestling game standards.

WWE 2K23 delivers an outstanding wrestling gaming experience, earning its status as the highest-rated professional wrestling video game since WWE '13. The inclusion of the WarGames match type and online multiplayer support for the Royal Rumble adds exciting layers to gameplay. Having not played a WWE game since SvR2011 I was excited to see what new features and improvements came about in my absence. Especially in CAW. I used to spend hours customizing every move and visual detail to my wrestlers. 
Oh boy... what a mixed bag we got here. 

Visuals look good but not exactly to the quality and smoothness I would expect from a game updated every year for the last 23 years in comparison to contemporaries like Madden, NBA2k or Fifa.

Despite this the download size is eggregious with it being 65gbs with another "synchronization update" after you boot the game. 
Which will then railroad you into creating a faction in some new mode they seem to really want you to be excited about. Everytime you accidentally select this option onwards sit tight for several minutes while it downloads more "updates". 

In case you thought you could blindly skip through all the new features nonsense by spamming the A button you now have to hold it down to progress to the next sections everytime you select something new. 

The Roster seems to have drifted towards a pay to unlock model like an EA title even to the extent of preventing you from downloading community CAWs that have clothing elements in them you have not yet purchased.

Speaking of the CAW section it feels like a step backwards with less to offer out the gate than previous versions from 10 years ago. The Community downloads area takes forever to load each page and does not have a intuitive search function with the community having to overcome this by using searchable custom "hashtags". 
If you are not discouraged by all of this and continue forward through with downloading CAWS you will likely then run into a "cloud synchronization error" which will crash the game and prevent you from launching the game again until you turn off cloud sync in the game's steam options. 

That being said I have already spent too much of my life playing this game. The core game that held me so long ago is still there, just mired under a myriad of bullsh!t. I still spend hours customizing CAWs and enjoy seeing what the community comes up with.

As a game, it's fun. Controls are comfortable, aesthetics are mostly pleasant to look at, and the gameplay modes are pretty fun if you're looking for something to kill some time. My favorite part of the game is easily the Creation Suite. You can apply just about ANYTHING you want to your custom wrestler and movesets. You can make really cool customized arenas and championships, however Custom Entrances are a bit buggy with certain elements (light show options, pyro options, etc.) I personally can't stand game modes like what MyFaction is, but that's just my personal taste. I'll get into that later.... Overall the game itself is average leaning more positive.

HOWEVER... This series of games has a very real issue I would like to shed some light upon. For starters, as I write this review on 1/20/2024, 2K have already begun promoting their next release, WWE 2K24. In the weeks leading up to these announcements and promotions, certain qualities of WWE 2K23 have begun to deteriorate and leave a lot to be desired. The BIGGEST flaw I've uncovered is with the online servers, particularly as it pertains to the Community Creations feature with Online. Trying to upload logos to the Community Creations Image Uploader website, only to be sitting here over an hour later and still can't download the logos I upload is ridiculous. Not to mention, trying to surf the Community Creations downloads tab, only to find that MAYBE half of the creations will actually load onto screen.

Now, I want to gripe on the MyFaction mode. I'll be honest, I have nothing positive to say about this mode. I've never cared for games that play like this mode does, it's just not for me. However, MyFaction has certain unlockable features that WOULD hypothetically make this game infinitely more playable, as they add in more and more unlockables as the games lifespan extends. The problem comes in when you realize these unlockables are exclusive to MyFaction, the only way to access them beyond the mode is to cut corners and mod the game. 2K really needs to consider making MyFaction unlockables accessible throughout the rest of the game in future installations.

To summarize, this is 2K/Visual Concepts second attempt at a WWE2K entry. 2K24 will be Attempt #3 to get it right. I'm cautiously optimistic, as someone who has played these games since I was in elementary school.

I came back to wrestling games after a hiatus from Smackdown Here comes the Pain. My main interest in the game was to download created wrestlers and lose myself in the game's Universe mode. I cannot do that without suffering. 

You cannot actually change the custom match tables without encountering bugs. For example, try setting random title matches on weekly shows with a low percentage: that makes it so there are title shots happen EVERY WEEK. Some characters, no matter their ranking and their popularity, get matches every week. The rivalry system gets old and repetitive very quickly.  


At full price, avoid it. Even at discounted prices, the review depends on what you are looking to get out of the game. MyGM and the card system is great if you like getting costumes you cannot reuse in your Universe mode. Great!!
Really fun game and I beat my opponent and got the Universal Champion from Universe mode I have to fight Roman in Wrestlemania Backlash.

Buyer beware:

If you are like me and wanted to play solely MyRise mode for some relaxed wrestling gameplay, don't buy this. This mode has forced objectives in way too many matches. If you don't complete them, you fail and have to rematch until you complete the totally random, arbitrary BS objective. For example: you have a great match, win by submission, but.. REMATCH, because you didn't do [obscure X move] on [Y character]. Absolute garbage. The person who made the decision to do this should never have a job in game design ever again. 

If, after reading this, you are crazy enough to still want to play, and you want to play MyRise mode with a custom move set, make the move set AFTER loading into MyRise. Otherwise, all your moves will be deleted, without warning, because.. reasons..

Universe mode is useless unless you like to keep track of everything on spreadsheets and use your imagination to create stories in your head. The Universe mode could be fixed if they brought back Create-a-story and let people import them into their universe.

Tag team rivalries are by far the worst thing in Universe mode. It will just put your superstars in solo matches. Nothing builds to anything that feels like an actual wrestling story line. 

If you like micro transactions and online spam then you may like this game. If you want a universe mode that builds stories without making it all up in your head then skip this game especially if you do CAW/CAS only universes.

At first, I was skeptical whether it was worth buying WWE 2k23, since it looked very similar to 2k22. However, the graphics and gameplay are much better and more elaborate. The only complaint I have is that the reversal indicators are very random. In many attacks you can't counter (regardless of your stamina and health), in others you can. The easy difficulty level doesn't feel that easy either. But all in all, it's fun.

The lengths 2K has gone to in order to prevent single-player modding in this game is straight up petty. I couldn't care less about the majority of the derpy content already in-game (not really my thing). I was mostly looking forward to modding things in, you know, so I could harmlessly enjoy the game I purchased the way I want to?

Nobody expects 2K to provide the modding tools or officially support modding in any way, but the least they could do is not go so far out of their way as to attack such a harmless practice. Their most recent patches destroyed their own passionate modding community, most of which have vowed never to purchased another 2K product again.

I guess this all seems like a sound financial decision (and fun way to shoot themselves in the foot) to 2K. Simply baffling...

WWE 2K23 so far are the best version of the 2K series but still lacking in some department. My issues with this game:

-finishing moves felt less satisfying because WWE 2K games are leaning towards realism

WWE 2K23 are still a good game for today's standard. here's hoping that 2K will tone down the realism a bit in WWE 2K24, and try to capture the gameplay of the old Smackdown vs. Raw games and mix it with 2K flavors.

I was excited to purchase this being the first wrestling game I've played since PS2. There a tons of content within the game and I've been enjoying experiencing all the features. I'm sure there is more content than I will ever be able to get through. 
As I put more hours into the game learning the ropes, I'm finding there are some broken parts of the matches.

The first issue I've found is that I can't always make a tag when I'm physically in reach or my teammates (even stunned in the corner with 3 mates by me).

The second is that there are many times where a rope break would be possible but an option was not there. (Drew McIntyre's meaty leg was under a rope while being pinned).
I hope these issues do not reoccur too often, I'm still giving this game some hope but those two broken functions were quite frustrating to experience. 

I felt like I was just spamming Y (reverse) for 10 minutes as a dead Jey Uso being tossed around as Jimmy Uso, Trick Williams and Drew McIntyre cheered from the corner, broke up pins but would not tap a homie on the chest as i'm stunned in our corner.

As usual it has the same problems as the other wwe 2k games. The counter prompts are off, not sure how they can continously do this, but least they keep that streak going right. In a game where countering is needed specially with the AI able to leap right to their feet with only a little stamina time after time, and recover swiftly when they don't auto jump to their feet. Not to mention being able to hit moves that you can't counter repeatedly, time after time. 

Like how hard is it to make sure your counter prompts are displaying at the appropriate time? Evidently impossible after all these years of making the same type of wrestling game they can't. Though once you get it down, or just keep getting lucky, the Y counter or triangle becomes fairly effective. Still won't help their autograbs, and moves where not even hitting the correct hold or attack button works. Which this is new to me, as not played a few of the WWE 2k games. not many I missed but evidently if they had this in the previous game I missed it.

The make an entrance is just blah, I prefer the older ones, which were more in depth, and easier to use then the current one is. It's hard to set things the way you want them as you really can't pause (or if you can I haven't found out how to after staring at the controls for several minutes at a time, looking for the way to pause it.) 

The faces are great they look like the wrestlers for the most part, the mouths and mouth sync is as wonky as ever, kiiiiinda scary ngl. Still it's an improvement over some of the others. The wrestling except for the above prompts showing up to late to actually counter the move with is rather enjoyable.

I do like the MyRise (haven't played anything else yet.) With interesting stories, still need to see if your choices actually matter, or if it's just the illusion of choice as in many other games. The fact I can play a female wrestler is great, with a good story, though not made it far I believe. 

Graphics are good, music is as ever fantastic. 

Button mashing for some things goes up at to slow of a pace, like I can kick out before a 1 count, but when they start dragging me to a corner and spose to press the B repeatedly it's not enough time, then of course it launches into a Y counter that the prompt ooooff course shows up to late to be useful. (yeah can you tell I'm annoyed by the lateness of the prompt). 

Overall a game to while away the hours, though the amount of frustration does build when you hit get into some types of matches. the more opponents there are either against you, or in a tag team the more frustration builds as you really have to stun everyone most times in order to get a pin. If not someone always manages to get their in time (doesn't matter how low their stamina is, or how badly they are hurt it seems) they'll just pop right into the ring, while your fresher teammates move like they are in tar. 

still I'd pick it up on sale, or if your looking for, or really into wrestling.

Gameplay
-------------

The most important part, the wrestling combat was fluid and excellent. Physics collision interaction between the wrestlers and with environment was very good and better than ever. Keyword WAS, however after one of the recent patch updates it has broken the hit detection consistency. Hits often don't connect anymore. Connecting with hits during crucial moments no longer connect creating frustrating moments and due to this also making the animations look really bad. Irish whipping moves from rope rebounds by the AI see them just stand and bounce of each other instead of executing their moves. 

One on One matches with the AI is too easy even on the hardest difficulty but mix in a few more wrestlers into a match and things get a lot more interesting and chaotic. The AI feels like it makes better decisions. Matches have a lot more drama and all the action and mayhem feels organic and great. The stamina as the match goes on longer and through a lot of damage should have had a much bigger impact but instead the characters can move and pull off moves with as ease as when at the start of match.

The presentation and lighting look great. The low detail referee needs a serious improvement. It may be a small thing in comparison to the others features that need improvement & have greater priority but the flat low detailed referee model can be jarring especially when most of the time the referee is in a totally statue still position with hardly any animation to show natural movement. Furthermore the referee can be slow and take too long to find a correct spot to start a pin count and on other occasions can be in front of the action obstructing the player view.

The roster this year included has many wrestlers and arenas from attitude era and ruthless aggression. There is the return of the likes of Kurt Angle, Cactus Jack, Kane, Rikishi, The Hurricane and others.

The story mode, MYRISE is also a decent play through. The men's Lock story campaign though is weaker than the women's Legacy campaign. Legacy has a much better story line, better matches and better and more unlockable items than the Lock story mode. The Lock story was slow at the start and better after second chapter (small spoiler) but it takes you out of the "WWE" and when the character returns the story halts and finishes quickly with only a grind of matches to recruit wrestlers in between.

The Cena Showcase mode was a disappointment. There is no commentary in the matches or voice over from Cena just generic looping music, ruining immersion. Then there is long stretches of video footage within the gameplay instead of short to the point dramatic video moments like in previous Showcase modes that smoothly transitioned back to gameplay. The videos also have a lot of censored blurring due to permission and license that 2K or WWE did not want to pay for. It is a big let down especially if anyone has played 2K15 and 2K16 Showcase mode to be able to compare to.

Create A Wrestler is fantastic. Able to customize nearly every part with fine detail and control. Only body type could have done with more choice with sliders.

Online
---------

The online servers were totally broken when the game launched and it took awhile for 2K fix it but so far it has been working fine in just accessing the online mode itself. 

MyFaction which is the cynical MTX(microtransaction) P2W(pay2win) mode 2K wants to make money with and there are wrestlers that are locked only to that mode unnecessarily only with intention to make users play MyFaction and generate money through loot box card packs. It was interesting to see so many different characters are available to play and have been designed by the developers but not included to play with the roster in normal mode. 

MyFaction is understandably a grind to progress and while a decent set of cards can be earned through normal progression and by completing objectives, the currency and progression is designed so that paying money for packs that are loot boxes is the preferred method 2K wants you to unlock the best characters with best stats to progress and win. 

The MyFaction mode is further aggressive to try and push players to purchase the virtual currency and loot box packs through not only the cost value of cards and packs but if receiving a duplicate card from a reward, the player receives a measly amount of MFP(MyFaction Points) to compensate for the duplicate that doesn't correspond with it's value such as a duplicate of a high ranking card. There are events that are locked if a player does not have a specific set of cards with no way to earn and unlock through normal play so paying to have a chance of getting a card is required. This also plays into the FOMO(fear of missing out) content with events that are time limited. The P2W structure is further evident in the multiplayer side of MyFaction where people who paid for the best cards will have a big advantage so no one risks even playing online in MyFaction portion of that mode.

Conclusion
--------------

There are areas that are still weak with room for improvement or missing features in comparison to older games in the series. A few odd omissions with entrance customization's and still some bugs & glitches during gameplay. In Universe mode, there is one particular quirk noticed with the mode where matches appear as tag matches but when entering the match it always becomes a singles fight.

Overall a decent package, with a strong roster, many gameplay modes that can create genuine cool wrestling moments with chaos and momentum swings back and forth, and that is not even fully mentioning MyGM and Universe mode.

In its current state however with the hit detection that was good before but now broken through an update by the developers this game cannot be recommended until that important core feature of a wrestling fighting game is fixed to a better level of polish that did exist when the game originally was released.

The game isn't perfect—far from it—but I can confirm that this game is really good. The game play is fun and addicting. MyGM is a fun game mode that takes a lot of strategy and thinking, and although it is not perfect, it is a huge improvement from 2K22's version. Myrise is fun, but I do kind of prefer the 2K22 version of it. But the big thing that makes the game shine the most is the community creations. So to end this review of the game, I would say this: be careful with how you close the game. I've had everything wiped twice now, so when you open the game, make sure you close it within the game itself; don't click alt + f4 or go to Steam and click the cancel launch button; it will most likely wipe your game.

Future Me: Never mind, just turn off cloud save; if you ever crash with it or click alt + f4 with it on, then your game save will be wiped.

I recently got my hands on W2K23, and as a casual gamer and wrestling enthusiast, I have to say it's been quite a ride. The game brings a lot to the table, especially for fans of the sport.

First off, the graphics are pretty impressive. The wrestlers look realistic, and the arenas are detailed. It adds a level of immersion that makes you feel like you're right there in the ring. The entrances are spot-on, capturing the essence of each wrestler's personality.

The gameplay is intuitive, even for someone like me who doesn't spend hours gaming every day. The controls are easy to pick up, with simple button combinations for executing moves. The variety of moves and the responsiveness of the controls keep the matches exciting and dynamic.

One of the highlights for me was the roster. W2K23 boasts an extensive lineup of wrestlers from different eras, allowing you to recreate classic matchups or dream bouts between your favorite superstars. The character creation feature is also a fun addition, letting you personalize your own wrestler and bring them into the mix.

The career mode is engaging, offering a storyline that keeps you invested in your created wrestler's journey. It's a nice touch that adds depth to the overall gaming experience. The backstage segments and interactions with other wrestlers add a layer of authenticity to the career mode.

However, it's not all perfect. The load times between matches can be a bit on the long side, and I've encountered a few minor glitches here and there. Nothing game-breaking, but it's worth mentioning.

In terms of game modes, W2K23 has a good mix. From standard one-on-one matches to tag teams and Royal Rumble, there's plenty to keep you entertained. The addition of online multiplayer adds another dimension, allowing you to test your skills against players from around the world.

In conclusion, W2K23 is a solid addition to the wrestling game genre. It caters well to both hardcore fans and casual gamers like myself. With its impressive graphics, accessible gameplay, and diverse roster, it's a title that's sure to provide hours of entertainment for wrestling enthusiasts.

WWE 2K23 presents a spectacular wrestling experience that will gratify aficionados of the genre. Even though it shows some significant advancements, there is still potential for development in other areas.

WWE 2K23 now offers smoother controls and a more responsive in-ring experience thanks to improved gameplay mechanics. The moves feel natural, and the updated submission system brings a fun new obstacle. The AI does, however, occasionally behave strangely, which takes away from the immersion.

WWE 2K23's roster is varied and offers a wide variety of both current and past WWE superstars. Players can now create distinctive personas thanks to the expanded character creation options. The visual presentation is impressive, featuring exquisite arenas and finely detailed character models that perfectly depict WWE events.

WWE 2K23 provides various game modes, including a career mode with gripping storylines and branching paths, are available to accommodate different player preferences. Some match types, however, may become repetitive over time due to a lack of innovation.

Even though the commentary is generally good, it could use more variety and lively dialogue to keep listeners interested throughout matches.

In conclusion, WWE 2K23 offers a satisfying wrestling experience thanks to its enhanced gameplay mechanics, varied roster, and stunning visuals. Fans of the genre will find plenty of excitement and entertainment in this most recent entry in the WWE video game franchise, despite some shortcomings in AI behavior and match variety..

WWE 2K23: A Step Forward with Room for Improvement

WWE 2K23 marks a commendable return to form for 2K Games in the realm of wrestling titles, showing significant progress from the infamous WWE 2K20. While not flawless, this instalment takes substantial strides in the right direction, introducing new and returning game modes, a plethora of customisation options, and delivering mostly smooth gameplay. However, as of this review, the game is not without its share of issues.

Overall, I would cautiously recommend this game.

The Good:

Expanded Customisation: Building on its predecessor, WWE 2K23 offers an extensive array of customisation options, allowing players to tailor their experience to a remarkable degree.

Up-to-Date Roster: The game maintains a mostly current roster, ensuring that players can engage with their favourite wrestling personalities from the present era.

Impressive Graphics: WWE 2K23 boasts stellar graphics, immersing players in a visually striking wrestling universe that adds to the overall gaming experience.

Engaging Story Mode: The inclusion of a decent story mode adds depth to the single-player experience, offering narrative-driven content for those who enjoy a more immersive journey.

The Bad:

Online Woes Persist: Unfortunately, the online mode still grapples with connectivity issues, hindering the overall experience for those seeking competitive or cooperative play.

Bugs and Glitches Linger: Despite strides made from the previous installment, WWE 2K23 is not entirely free from bugs and glitches.

Attempted Removal of Modding Support: A notable drawback is their attempt of removing modding support, limiting the community's ability to enhance and extend the game's longevity through user-generated content.

Building upon the successes of WWE 2K22, WWE 2K23 showcases a what-could-be positive trajectory for the series. However, persistent online challenges, occasional technical hiccups, and concerns about DLC practices underscore that there's still work to be done. As 2K Games continues to refine its wrestling titles, there is hope for further improvement. Here's to hoping that the developers learn from both the successes and shortcomings of WWE 2K23, paving the way for an even more polished experience in future iterations.

Overall Rating: 7/10

Not a huge leap forward over the last game but it looks great, plays super smooth and the level of customisation options is insane.
Create your own custom shows, play dream matches and thanks to the community creations you can download wrestlers from the past and others who aren't in the WWE and put them in your roster.
The community is so excellent, people are constantly uploading wrestler's latest costumes and gear so you can keep everything up to date it's so cool.
Some community made wrestlers look kind of dodgy but other creators are so talented they often legit look like official models which could have shipped with the game.
Ever wanted to see CM Punk fight Seth Rollins or Brock Lesnar fight Hogan? You can do that.

One thing i wish they would add to these games is the option to customise entrance music with MP3's. It would be so easy to do especially on PC. I'm sure there was a wrestling game on the OG Xbox back in the day where you could do that.

Having not played a WWE game since 2008, I was hesitant to purchase WWE 2K23. Yet, I decided to pull the trigger and give the game a try. I have always enjoyed the older WWE games, especially the SVR series. However, I took a break from it due to the new direction the games were taking. It was not until last year I started to regain interest in the WWE games when I began hearing about the massive improvements to the 2K series. Now 2K23 is far from perfect, but it is heading back in the right direction. As someone who enjoys the storytelling aspect in games, I am really enjoying showcase mode and MyRise the most. To be able to play through John Cena's career, arguably one of the GOAT, is a really cool experience. In MyRise, you can create your own story, join factions, and become the ultimate champion. WWE 2K23 is a great wrestling game. I have not had this much fun from a WWE game since SVR. I am glad to say once again that I am excited to see, whats to come for future WWE games!
It's better than AEW Fight Forever and looks great.

After over 300 hours of messing around with 2k22, they ruined it at the end of the year. I can't download CAWs, and I don't enjoy trying to rebuild dozens of the old wrestlers I like from the past. So after fighting it for a while, I decided to download this.

While downloading, I watched someone play the MyRise for a bit, and it's horrible! Cheesy and only like 2 hours of non-gameplay story. Then when it finished downloading, I went into the CAWs, and there were tons of people missing that others had made in 2k22. None of the classic New Japan wrestlers were there, and some of the rings people made from the last game were missing. So I uninstalled it and requested a refund. I guess I'll wait until it goes on a bigger sale or just skip the games for a few years; maybe they will be able to afford to keep their games running for more than two years at a time in the future.

WWE 2K23 lengthy review from a hardcore WWE Fan and game designers' perspective
I love the feel of the game and how close to reality it feels, but that does not mean the game needs to cut off from the random OMG moments. The lights added backstage are a cool concept and should be expanded on further, which is very likely as stated in reviews. 
Improvements - 
More running reversals into finishers (for example - deep six and sister abigail can be hit if finisher is hit at the right time when the opponent is running)
Combo + Grapples. There are a lot of pacing issues faced by the game due grapple moves being one move only, then the player has to hit yet another grapple move and it breaks momentum and reduces the immersion. The execution should be more in the style of Northern Lights suplex and/or comeback move.
Fix the submission technique, button mashers are annoying.
Allow us to do changes to the in-game model.
My faction models should be transferrable to main game. Ban them from online
Better Ai for dragging and corner finishers. Its super annoying for a person who does that for content.
Make the game difficult or add more randomness
Rollout is a terrible system
Better tired finishers
And FIX online.
Universe mode needs a lot of detail work. Here are a few things which are very possible knowing the limitaions of the game-
Better UI
Better flow between the matches, which can be fixed by just adding a next button, cool transitions and promos. '
Best idea is mixing the MyGm as a concept.
Champions should feel like one. Adding commentary for how long they have been champions, game already calculates that so why not let Michael Cole exclaim it for certain superstars. Longest reigning champions, Best challenger and No. 1 contender match commentary.
Drafting (maybe...)
Better cutscenes

Bought this solely for the purpose of playing with friends and having a good time when we all hang out together, and this definitely served the purpose.

Pros:

1) Simple controls that are easy to pick up. You don't NEED to know some crazy button combos to be competent at the game.

2) A properly huge roster of characters to choose from that spans over decades of WWE. You may be a fan, a causal who remembers a couple of wrestlers or just pick someone who looks cool to you, there is a wrestler for everyone.

3) Pretty decent graphics for what it is.

Cons:

1) Reversals in fights can make each match last for quite some time. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, but if you want snappy match-ups to allow for quick clashes and passing of controllers, this is probably not the game.

WWE 2K23 truly impresses with its clean Superstar models,graphics and UIs, making it a treat for fans like me who always support and adore WWE games. The game's modding support adds a satisfying layer of customization to enhance the overall experience, and on the Rog Ally handheld console, it runs flawlessly, allowing me to play it on the go.

Featuring John Cena on the cover and as the Showcase star is a brilliant choice, and the MyRise storyline adds an extra layer of enjoyment. As a fan of FIFA's Ultimate Team, I find the MyFaction mode appealing, though it could benefit from more advanced gameplay and a marketplace.

Overall, I enjoy the game and would give it 5 stars, but the server issues, such as difficulty finding opponents, CC crashes, and lost connections, are a major disappointment for me. Despite these setbacks, my loyalty and love for WWE games still shine through.

BUYER BEWARE: When I loaded up this game tonight I discovered ALL of my progress was gone! I researched the issue and apparently it's seemingly common glitch that they have been unable to patch. Now I am usually the kind of gamer that waits for sells and rarely ever buys at full price... However due to this massive glitch, idk you might be better off trying to find a pirated version of the game. Normally I wouldn't openly advocate for that, but even though I purchased the game on sell, I feel I have been ripped-off.

Before this happened I honestly would've said this is the best wresting game ever and would've highly recommended it, even for older wresting fans! It really caters to all eras of WWF/WWE, but this is seriously a critical glitch and it seems this game got rushed in development before all of the serious bugs and glitches were fixed,

Last wwe 2k game that I played was 2k19. Was hoping for major improvements and am disappointed. 
-Game glitches and freezes
-Was expecting an updated create-a-finisher with more ways to create a finisher, but that feature was completely removed from the game
-No new match types, nor did they bring back some of the great match types such as slobber knocker matches
-No way to interfere in matches like how it happens in the show
-Some superstars still do their iconic taunts wrong (i.e. Roman Reign’s corner superman punch move has the same wrong taunt)
-Limited ways to perform a finisher(i.e. for the move “spear”, why can’t they make it both a corner finisher and a running finisher, instead of having user consume two finisher slots in create-a-moveset?
And the list of cons go on. Only the graphics feel updated. I think they might be doing this on purpose to have people buy their games every year, which I won’t be doing. Doubt I will be buying any of the WWE games before WWE 2k27, if that’ll be the name of the game in 2027.

This is basically the same game as WWE 2K22. The only noticeable changes outside of the Wargames mode:

+improved lighting system that makes the game look even better if you have a PC capable of maxing out the settings (at low settings, it just looks like WWE 2k22 with heavier contrast)
+improvements in the eyes of the models  (the wrestlers don't look like goofy bug-eyed weirdos anymore). 
+there are also improvements in the wrestlers' hair, but it's on a case by case basis. e.g. long haired HHH's hair (you can unlock him on showcase) looks decent now compared to 2k22, but Bret Hart still looks like Buckwheat. The CAW hairs are still crap, though. I don't know if they're ever going to fix that.
+the window for reversals is shortened so you're going to really have to work at reversing moves now.

Other than that, it's still got the same problems as the previous iteration - including freakishly slow servers that make browsing the community creations 10 times longer (I was going to refund this game, but ended up blowing through the 2 hour window just by browsing the community creations. And it's not like I have slow internet - I finished downloading the game in an hour - and that's another disadvantage to this game. It's 80GB now, compared to WWE2K22's 55GB, while providing similar amounts of content.) 

Basically, get this game if you still don't have WWE 2K22. If you already have 2K22, this game is not worth the price even at 50% off. Wait for an even deeper discount (if it comes at all, 2K is stingy) or wait for 2K24 and see if it adds a lot more to warrant the price tag.

WWE 2K23 offers a mix of solid gameplay and engaging wrestling action, capturing the essence of the WWE world effectively. The in-ring experience remains entertaining, with engaging matches and realistic animations. However, the game is marred by the presence of numerous bugs and technical issues, which can be frustrating and disruptive to the overall experience.

One notable drawback is the player career mode, which falls flat in terms of excitement and engagement. It lacks the depth and storytelling elements that could make it a compelling journey for players to experience. The potential for an immersive career mode is there, but WWE 2K23 fails to fully capitalize on it, leaving players longing for a more fulfilling single-player experience.

In conclusion, WWE 2K23 offers enjoyable wrestling gameplay, but its bugs and the underwhelming player career mode prevent it from reaching its full potential. Wrestling fans may find some enjoyment here, but the game falls short of being a knockout title in the WWE gaming franchise.

Fun game but filled with issues even after the latest update. In my first match with the game (the first showcase match) Van Dam's arm got stuck attached to a broken chair and was glitching across the ring for the entire rest of the match, even cutscenes did not fix it. I also had my game crash multiple times while trying to download content off Community Creations, and most recently (like probably 3 minutes before writing this review) had my savegame corrupt itself because the game softlocked while trying to delete a wrestler and it ended up wiping my ENTIRE save data. It has its moments and some fun game modes (MyGM is awesome), but as someone who never played WWE 2K20, this is the buggiest experience I've had trying to navigate a WWE game.

EDIT: Right after writing this, I went back into the game to try and atleast restore my Showcase progress, and not only did the video of Cena talking leading up to the Van Dam match lag an insane amount (I have an Intel Core i-5 and Geforce 3060, it ran just fine the other night), but the game proceeded to crash right after completing the match, causing me to lose the progress I had literally just made. I'm over it.

I'll preface this by saying 2k23 is a fine game, after all updates. But the litany of minor problems can build up in annoyances. Controller issues, model issues, Universe mode issues, creation suite issues, they may be minor but there's *so many* of them that they all start to add up.

On top of that, the game's single player content just feels gutted compared to previous years, still. It's crawling back, but it's not there yet. And while MyFaction may be a reflection of the state of things in modern gaming, it's still glorified gambling and deeply annoying to constantly be prompted to play it any time you start up the game.

I used to be a wrestling fan but haven't watched the product in about 9 years. I always like the WWE games, the last one I played has CM Punk on the cover, can't remember the year off the top of my head. I decided to give this game a try as I always liked doing the career mode which this games calls My Rise. Being as that I have not watched in so long I have no idea who about 98% of who is on the roster. I played The Lock (male) career and it was ok as I really didn't like the story, so I switched the female My Rise and it has a much better story. Granted the voice acting is cheesy but that was to be expected. The biggest problem with My Rise is that it will eventually get stuck on a forever loading screen that you cannot escape. I have hit this wall and can no longer progress in the game. I could restart but I put about 22 hours of total gameplay into it and I am not prepared to do that. If I had known about this bug which I now have learned is very common, I never would have bough this game.  Spending some time researching a solution to this forever loading screen, it seems that there is none and it has been an issue for at least 6 months. I will not be playing this game again unless there is a fix, just too bad the devs already got my money so it doesn't really matter at this point.

A Slam Dunk of Entertainment - WWE 2K23 Review

WWE 2K23 is an absolute triumph in the world of professional wrestling video games, delivering an experience that's nothing short of electrifying. As a longtime fan of both the WWE and the gaming industry, I couldn't be more thrilled with what this installment brings to the table.

First and foremost, the graphics in WWE 2K23 are jaw-dropping. The attention to detail in the character models is impeccable, with each superstar looking more lifelike than ever before. From the sweat glistening on their brows to the way their gear shimmers under the arena lights, the visual fidelity in this game is top-notch. It's like having a ringside seat to all the action, and it's clear that the developers spared no expense in making sure every detail was just right.

But it's not just about looks; WWE 2K23 also packs a serious punch when it comes to gameplay. The controls are intuitive, making it easy for newcomers to jump right in while offering enough depth to keep veterans engaged. The new grappling system is a game-changer, adding an extra layer of strategy to each match. Whether you're locking in a submission hold or executing a high-flying move from the top rope, every action feels responsive and impactful.

One of the standout features of WWE 2K23 is the robust roster of superstars. With a mix of current talent, legends, and surprise appearances, there's no shortage of dream matchups to explore. The game's career mode is a true highlight, allowing players to create their own wrestler and guide them through the highs and lows of a WWE career. The storytelling in this mode is immersive, with plenty of twists and turns to keep you invested.

Online multiplayer is another area where WWE 2K23 shines. The matchmaking system is efficient, ensuring that you'll always find a challenging opponent. Whether you're teaming up with friends in tag team matches or going head-to-head in a no-holds-barred brawl, the online experience is a blast.

And let's not forget about the presentation. WWE 2K23 nails the atmosphere of a WWE event, from the raucous crowd reactions to the dynamic commentary that adds to the excitement. It's clear that the developers understand what makes WWE special, and they've captured that magic in the game.

In conclusion, WWE 2K23 is a must-have for wrestling fans and gamers alike. It combines stunning visuals, deep gameplay, an extensive roster, and an immersive career mode to create an unforgettable experience. Whether you're reliving classic rivalries or creating new ones, WWE 2K23 delivers the thrill of the squared circle like never before. Get ready to step into the ring and experience the excitement of WWE in a whole new way – this game is a slam dunk of entertainment!

After putting 184 hours into this game since its release, i can definitely recommend this game to any fan of the WWE. Showcase mode was a fun trip down memory lane through John Cenas career, although is probably the weakest mode due to little to no replay value and some very tedious objectives. Both my rise campaigns are a huge step up over 2K22, Both the lock and the legacy telling decent WWE TV style stories. My GM is fun to play around with (although as an achievement hunter it is a nightmare), and universe mode is still just okay. Most of my 184 hours has been spent in my faction however, which has a good variety of modes and a very addictive gameplay loop. 
My one real problem with it being that a lot of superstars and legends are locked behind packs, only having rare cards such as amethyst and diamond cards. Packs are a grind to earn, and makes it even more of a grind to get such wrestlers for my collection. This is quite disappointing, as i can't play as favourites such as HBK, Undertaker and Triple H... unless I drop nearly £100 of real money on packs, which feels very heavily incentivized... and kinda scummy.

It's an above average WWE game, but not without its flaws. The biggest disappointment was Cena's showcase mode. It was a really cool idea that I was excited for, but was executed very poorly. There's no commentary throughout the matches (although the royalty free music is actually kind of cool), the cutscenes are way too long, and the whole flow of the mode is a total mess; all of the matches are way out of chronological order for no reason. I'd say Cena's cutscenes recording the voiceover was cool, but it's painfully obvious that he's reading a piece of paper or teleprompter. Also, they obnoxiously blur out 90% of the faces and objects in the live action cutscenes for no good reason, unless there's something peculiar about referee Charles Robinson's face we should all know about.

This was also my first time trying the new combat system as I didn't play 2K22. I have mixed feelings about it. On one hand, it feels more realistic and fun with more than one reversal type and the added combos. On the other, I feel pretty helpless when I lose the upper hand for even a second as there's no way for me to tell how to counter my opponent except for mashing the buttons, hoping they hit the move I'm trying to counter.

I give it a 7/10. It's a good game and worth a solid binge for universe mode alone, but I'll likely never play it again when a better one comes out down the road. The best WWE games are the ones you return to even after they become "outdated" (e.g. 2K19, 2K14, SvR '06-'11, HCTP, etc.).

TL;DR | Good, but not great. Get it on sale.

EDIT: I should have also mentioned that the roster is actually pretty great with no glaring omissions aside from Chris Jericho, but that's just the way it is with AEW being as big as it is these days. And the main pro of Cena's showcase is a list of unique and cool unlockables, but it still doesn't justify how mediocre the overall showcase experience was.

The most fun I've had in a wrestling game since WWE 2K14. This game is very Ucey.

I really want to like this game. 

I still play it everyday, and I'm enjoying the nostalgia and re-learning all the wrestlers and move-sets, but..

...so many QoL annoyances, never-ending money-sinks, intentionally hard to grind characters, and game-breaking bugs... it's beyond ridiculous. 

Overpriced game, overpriced DLC, INCREDIBLY overpriced in-game purchases.

Multiplayer hardly works, and only on standard.. if you're trying to play MyFaction good luck,
I've sat in queue for hours and still haven't got one single match.

If you play online normal, people will DC if losing, they will use macros to spam buttons so you cannot get them to tapout or they will tap you out instantly.. super fun. The whole UI is a clunky mess, and laggy connections make the game unplayable for anyone outside your immediate region. 

It's a fun game, but things like.. if you shift-tab to open steam overlay mid-match for messages or anything else, it will swap your controls to keyboard-mouse and will not change to controller until you restart the match. In Online play, guess how fun it is to start a match and not be able to move. They pin you right away and you just screwed up a fatal 4way that took forever to fill up. Not making many friends that way.

No in game or even lobby chat..? Only voice..? How is this not MORE toxic and less efficient than being able to say things to strangers you're trying to coordinate with..? Just seems silly.

For a genre and sport that has always centered around multiplayer, how the hell do you screw that up?
All the extra gimmicks and shine they throw at you so you'll buy more stuff, instead of fixing all the dumb broken and blatant bugs that plague the game. gogo late stage capitalism. 

It's really, really disappointing. 

Hopefully they fix it up, but my guess is they'll soak up as much money as they can and then push out 2k24 with the same business model.

They spend $20-$40 million and years to make a game, and can't do it as well as indie studios..?

I know games are a business, but they are also art. Using them as pure vehicles to transfer money seems.. disgusting. I've been playing vids since ET on atari (dunno how I didn't walk away from games altogether), and nowadays it feels more and more like intentional betrayal, sitting around a boardroom table discussing not how they can help their customer base enjoy their product, but how they can squeeze more of your money away from you on a game that will be defunct soon (and essentially already is).

I wish there was a way to convince corporations that caring about their customers will actually increase their profits instead of a fast boost that leaves people disappointed and annoyed. 

I'll change this if the devs suddenly decide to give a shit about players and fixing bugs. 
What a motivation. I'll be here holding my breath. 

(side note, the forum mods for 2k23 are overzealous; i was trying to stop a fight happening in my thread and said 'we like to beat the shit out of each other, but lets keep it in game,' was immediately contacted by a mod talking down to me, 'you've been caught' using 'completely unnecessary language' and other such power-tripping nonsense. So heads up.)

Again, it is a super fun game, and I've met some fantastic people on here, and they DO get a lot right.. but for these prices, I'm not looking for 'okay.' This is supposed to be AAA quality, not beta. 

edit: only 1.7% of players have completed one single Proving Grounds Chapter (there is a few) with similar achievements under 5%, so that shows you how little of a MyFaction presence there is

EDIT: i put another 68 hours in since the review, played thru 4 new MyF pack releases, as well as a 6.8gb update that didn't do anything except add one pack of cards.

MyF is still broken, no one is ever on, and they are still charging for incredibly over-priced MyF items that you can only use in MyF, supposedly against other MyF players. 

Problem is, again, there are none. So there is no payoff, no reward, just grinding dumb fights over and over to get more packs to try to get the 'good' cards that are all duplicates of the same 10 wrestlers.

dumb. dumb. dumb. dumb. dumb.

Don't buy 2k24, don't support predatory and apathetic game developers.

So I have 2k15, 2k17, 2k20, 2k22 and 2k23 and by far, the controls and gameplay of this version are the best. The customization is not as well thought out or implemented as some (say 2k20 for example), but it's fine. Unfortunately, the worst thing, that has carried over consistently from 2k17 to this one is save game corruption. There has never been a fix regardless of version, and it always happens (more so during 'patch upgrades' but sometimes even then it happens within a version). There is nothing more frustrating than getting into the story line, getting proficient at the controls and getting to the good part, only to fail to load the save game on the next run and having to start over.

No more for me, I don't have the kind of time it would take to luck my way to completion. Good luck to anyone else foolish enough to give more than .99 to these guys for an issue over seven years and seven versions old. Shame...

WWE 2K23 brings a fresh and visually stunning wrestling experience to the table. Compared to WWE 2K14, the graphics are a major standout, with incredibly lifelike character models and vibrant arenas. Gameplay is smoother and more responsive, offering a diverse roster of both classic and current superstars. While there are occasional hiccups and AI quirks, they're less bothersome than in WWE 2K14. This installment feels like a step in the right direction for the franchise, delivering an immersive and dynamic wrestling simulation. It retains the essence of WWE 2K14's charm while modernizing the series for today's gaming audience.

MyRise kinda sucks. Women's wrestling sucks. Game needs better blood effects. 
Bought it on sale for $30. Maybe wait till its $19. 
Graphics and physics are incredible, but MyRise is like a ride on a train. It's linear as fuck and has a small handful of forks in the road, but the outcome of matches doesn't matter because the match will just restart if you didnt complete it how the game tells you to. 
There's 2 separate stories, "The Lock" takes place from a mans perspective and its very specific. You start off as an experienced wrestler taking his first steps into the WWE getting a huge push from corporate. You get the intercontinental title your very first match. It's interesting, sure, but I would much rather start off as a nobody rookie in the indie leagues. 
I forget what the other story option is called, but you start off as the daughter of a WWE Diva "legend" from the attitude era. Thing is im not interested in women's wrestling and less interested in playing as a female character so I'll pass. If I'd had know this prior to paying for the game, I would have passed on picking this game up, even on sale. 

I don't think I'm the target audience. I'm a 33 year old man who grew up watching the attitude era since '97. Not exactly sure who they're trying to market to with this game, but it ain't me.

Idk if i should put recommended or not. 
The Cena showcase AMAZING. The transition from video feed, to in game cut scene to controlled gameplay was a masterpiece. 
The story is... there... kinda feels like the idea with 2K19 Buzz stuck around and we just capture the best hits. The choices are minor at best and don't even give the illusion that what i do matters. Couple of them do per storyline. 
For those who are unfamiliar you have a male story-line as the Lock, a seasoned wrestler from outside WWE making his debut. And the female story-line as LJ (or little Justine) an up and comer from a legendary wrestler bloodline Justine (2K's OC). 
The GM mode is fine. Some improvements but more of the same. Idk i have fun turning my brain off and getting my butt handed to me by NPCs.
The factions game mode is not for me. Great variety, 2Ks cash cow for micro-transactions that don't affect anything else in the game so it's fine. Huge variety of wrestlers to play in (mostly) the worst type of matches. 4v4s. (see below)

Gameplay:
More of the same. New counter system that feels.. weird.. not good or bad weird just weird. You have your typical press Y (i play on an xbox controller) to counter SOMETIMES. Other times press X or A or B. Combos and grapples require you to guess one of the three buttons whereas strikes or beginning of combos and finishers use Y. Timings for when to press seem weirdly timed and wrestlers tend to favor either light (X) combos and attacks or heavy (A) but will use the other one to remove the chance of always countering. Almost every 4th combo ends up being a throw (B) and the AI always uses a lot of those so its easy to predict them.
 
Now this will be a reenactment of me playing a game with tag or a manager on the opposing side: STOP TAKING CONTROL OF MY FREAKING CHARACTER GAME!!!!!! 
2v2s or more basically guarantee that you gotta win your current fight, knock off any other opponents and in the short window of stunned time you have to pin your original target. Personally i cheese it with submissions cause i find that system BORING. The AI doesn't protect you well enough to pin.
Fun to Play

I have not purchased a wrestling game since Smackdown vs. Raw 2007, which featured the best GM Mode in our current timeline of reality. That being said, 2k23 is a terrific video game and feels like a wrestling game for all wrestling fans, new and old. The game has good controls, a good roster, and an enjoyable variety of gamemodes. Although new GM modes are more "arcadey" than the SvR iterations, they do a good job of scratching the itch. Currently I am invested in playing Universe mode and have been having a blast playing as my custom superstar! 
This game is NOT bug free however... there are glitches that get in the way such as in tag team matches occasionally when you tag your partner in you switch controls to them and are unable to switch back to the superstar you selected to play as... most glitches can just be worked around or restarting the match works about 85% of the time. 
This is definitely the VERY BEST of the WWE 2k franchise thus far.

I remember playing wrestling games both WWE/WCW back on the old consoles. This was the first 2k WWE game I played and honestly it will be the last. I was so disappointed with my purchase. This game does have nice graphics (not sure about the faces, they look weird) probably would look better on a high end GPU. The story in myrise was horrible. Its short and character choices don't really matter in the long run of it. The AI and difficulty hurt the overall experience, making it such a chore to complete. If you make a mistake or get countered (which will happen when u least expected)  your AI opponent will mercilessly beat your ass until you break its momentum. AI opponent does have an advantage over you it can recover faster (without using resources), can counter anytime (no matter status), and gain a stupid amount of momentum really quick. Doesn't matter the difficulty you set it to once you lose control of the match its hard to get it back. Its a lot worse with multiple opponents in 3 ways and fatal 4 ways. Also if the AI puts you in a submission its game over. What I mean is, the submission bar drops so fast when trying to break the hold is like competing in a button mashing mini game with an opponent player using a turbo controller against you. It doesn't matter if you are full health once it holds you in a submission its over fast. It completely unforgivable how horribly unbalance the AI submission is. The only time I even managed to breakout (at full health mind you) was when my tag partner broke the hold just before I lost. Instead of having fun and enjoying myself, I get annoyed and frustrated with this game. I have only seen a few glitches mainly both showcase and universe mode would drop fps and then freeze the game. Glitched wrestlers arms would unhinge from the body and flail about like those inflatable tube men at car dealerships. Its down right funny and disturbing at the same time. Options are also limited in game, cant upload music for themes don't know why. I don't recommend this game to other players it was very disappointing.

Good.

Honestly, a surprising step up from 2k22 in nearly every way. 

I can't attest to every mode in the game because I've never touched things like My Faction, but I've since uninstalled 2k22 since I don't see me ever going back after playing this one.

The roster is pretty stacked with a lot of my personal favorites unlocked through gameplay rather than having to be bought in DLC packs like last year. My Rise is muuuuuch more focused this time around with more cutscenes, a interesting unique story for both male and female characters, and most importantly: a clear indication of what is a main story progression, a side story, or just a challenge.

My GM is fantastic this time around with a ton more match types, triple threat & fatal fourways, the ability to end rivalries outside of PPVs, new power cards, a new 'shake-up' system, the ability to have up to four brands duke it out at once (either as NPCs or with friends), as well as a few other quality of life improvements that makes it way more fun to play.

The best part is that every update no longer requires you to download the entire game file again this year; something that is much appreciated. 

Still a shame that there's no way to add custom music without modding the game, and mixed-gender matches are still out.

Overall, though, this is a shockingly solid wrestling game for anyone who's a fan of the genre.

I've been playing every major WWE game since 2003. So after playing the WWE 2k series, I didn't initially like the changes made in WWE 2k20 (the only game in the series I barely played). I didn't like WWE 2k22 at first either, the combos and animations didn't seem right but, I grew to like it as time went on. Now with WWE 2k23, I fully embraced the gameplay and enjoyed the game overall. The game reminds me a lot of the Smackdown vs Raw series in terms of gameplay, the controls might be different but, that mix of realism and wrestling arcade action is back. 

The roster is what I wanted, the best of the 80s, 90s and 00 for the most part. The John Cena showcase brought back a lot of WWE stars ruthless aggression stars that I am a fan of. Gameplay and roster is what matters the most to me and to me it delivered in that department. The base game roster is good enough for me but, I bought the deluxe addition anyways. 

I don't care for MyRise, I never liked it the career modes in WWE 2k games dating back to WWE 2k15. The storylines in modern WWE games are not enjoyable so I'm not interested and I won't try this one either so I won't factor that in to my review. 

The graphics look good overall but, they aren't going to impress you for a next gen game. The gameplay is improved from 2k22 slightly and it feels better. There are some occasional glitches but, it's not gamebreaking, My complaints with this game are minor ones. 

The online community has done a fantastic job with this game. Guys like "WhatstheStatus" are constantly putting out hidden contend from the games files and it essentially becomes DLC. For example, a 2005 Rey Mysterio wasn't in the game but, uploaded a customized younger Rey Mysterio model with 2005 Rey Mysterio's clothing and found some way of getting his hidden theme song to play with the proper commentary for Rey. It's pretty cool. The online community keeps this game going strong all year. 

I did run into an issue though, I was deleting a created wrestler I did not want and the game seemed to have froze because the game wouldn't move for minutes and it's not like this created wrestler was anything special either. All my data was gone and I had to restart which takes me to the showcase...

The Showcase with John Cena was okay but, the wrestler entrances are not included and it's also a requirement to beat to this mode in order to unlock all John Cena's attires. I already paid for the "Supercharged" DLC which unlocks almost everything but, beating the John Cena mode is still required. When all my data got corrupted for some strange reason, I had do it all again and it felt unnecessary since the Showcase is essentially just a long tutorial mode. 

Outside of that, the game has a solid roster. They FINALLY brought back three different version of Hulk Hogan. There a lot of fantasy matchups that can be made in this game and I really enjoy that. I casually watch wrestling these days but, I've continued to play the games and this one of the better ones I played in 20 years.

At a certain point, it just comes down to the game's fault.

I didn't know that they took out body morphing until I owned the game. I know people play for different reasons, but I don't see myself buying another WWE2k game. I still have mixed feelings, and I am an unusual type of player. Let's make a list:

The good: 
Face animations are great, and are very interesting to watch during the match.
I like custom matches, options, and how statistics that once did nothing now do something interesting for non-played wrestlers.
There are still some good CAW options even though I wish there were more.
Matches are fun to watch.
Your mileage may vary, but I think this was better than PC versions of 2k16, 2k17, 2k18, 2k19, and 2k20. It has more good options, and you don't need to do as much to have a good spectator match.

The Bad:
Some things seem to have been removed that should have stayed in, and some things stayed in that should have been removed.
While face animations are good, many other animations seem to have issues, and the ai struggles to perform proper moves still, although it is not as bad as 2k20.
Like I said, morphs are good, and I prefer to have good options added instead of good options taken away.
Some issues have remained for the entire lifetime of this series: 

   KOs don't work right, and odd things like light attacks knock characters out, and there is no 10-count or 3 times lifting the arm, it is instant. 

   Submission holds still do not work right. There is no way to slip out of a submission hold or let it go. The only way that a wrestler breaks out of submission hold is to do an attack that works. This is not how WWE       works.

   I still don't like signature and finisher bars. This makes no sense, when really these are done when an    opponent is scripted as too weak to prevent you from doing them, not when you get a bar going to a     certain progress threshold.

Many good things have to be unlocked, and I hate this, and always have. I should not be prevented from downloading a CAW just because they want me to play a game mode that I don't like.
